contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Politician | name = Count Baltzar von Platen | image =Painting of Baltzar von Platen (1766-1829).jpg | caption = | birth_date ={{Birth-date|29 May 1766|29 May 1766}} | birth_place = [[Rügen]], [[Swedish Pomerania]] | residence = | death_date = {{Death-date|6 December 1829|6 December 1829}} | death_place =[[Oslo|Christiania]], [[Norway]] | office = [[List of Norwegian Prime Ministers|Governor of Norway]] | term_start =1827 | term_end = 1829 | predecessor = [[Johan August Sandels]] | successor = [[Johan Caspar Herman Wedel-Jarlsberg]] | constituency = | office2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | constituency2 = | office3 = | term_start3 = | term_end3 = | predecessor3 = | successor3 = | constituency3 = | party = | religion = | occupation = Naval officer, Architect | majority = | relations = | spouse =Hedvig Elisabeth Ekman | partner = | children = | website = | footnotes = }} Count '''Baltzar Bogislaus von Platen''' (29 May 1766 – 6 December 1829) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] naval officer and statesman.<ref name=ne /> He was born on the island of [[Rügen]] (now Germany) to Philip Julius Bernhard von Platen, [[List of Swedish Field Marshals|Field Marshal]] and the Swedish [[Governor-General in the Swedish Realm|Governor General]] of [[Swedish Pomerania|Pomerania]], and Regina Juliana von Usedom. ==Swedish Navy== At age 13 Baltzar entered the [[Royal Swedish Navy]] where he served with distinction until resigning in 1800, having attained the rank of Captain. ==Göta Canal== Following the revolution in 1809 he became a member [[Privy Council of Sweden|Government]] and, in the following year, received a promotion to Rear Admiral. He was also made chairman of the [[Göta Canal]] directorate charged with constructing a canal across Sweden. The canal, following a design by [[Thomas Telford]], would only be completed in 1832, after von Platen's death, but during its construction, he did discover two skilled mechanical engineering brothers [[John Ericsson]] and [[Nils Ericson]]. ==Honors== He was elected a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] in 1815. He was appointed [[Governor of Norway]] on 26 November 1827, a position which he held until his death in [[Oslo|Christiania]], the [[Norway|Norwegian]] capital, on 6 December 1829. ==Burial site== He was married to Hedvig Elisabeth Ekman. Baltzar von Platen's grave is at the side of the Göta Canal in [[Motala]], where it is something of a tourist attraction, especially for canal visitors. ==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=ne>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Baltzar von Platen |encyclopedia=[[Nationalencyklopedin]] |url=http://www.ne.se/baltzar-von-platen/284243 |language=Swedish |accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref> }} {{S-start}} {{Succession box | before=[[Johan August Sandels]]| title=[[List of Norwegian Prime Ministers|Governor of Norway]] | years=1827–1829 | after=[[Johan Caspar Herman Wedel-Jarlsberg]]}} {{S-end}} {{Authority control|VIAF=40279033}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Platen, Baltzar | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Swedish politician | DATE OF BIRTH =29 May 1766 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Rügen]], [[Swedish Pomerania]] | DATE OF DEATH =6 December 1829 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Oslo|Christiania]], [[Norway]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Platen, Baltzar}} [[Category:1766 births]] [[Category:1829 deaths]] [[Category:Platen family|Baltzar]] [[Category:Swedish nobility]] [[Category:Swedish people of German descent]] [[Category:Members of the Privy Council of Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish admirals]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:19th-century Swedish people]]
